definition: Chiang Ching-kuo (1910-1988), son of Chiang Kai-shek 蔣介石|蒋介石, Guomindang politician, president of ROC 1978-1988
surname Jiang/refers to Chiang Kai-shek 蔣介石|蒋介石
classics/sacred book/scripture/to pass through/to undergo/to bear/to endure/warp (textile)/longitude/menstruation/channel (TCM)/abbr. for economics 經濟|经济[jing1 ji4]
surname Jing
surname Guo
country/nation/state/national/CL:個|个[ge4]

sentences.english: It was his son, Chiang Ching-kuo, who will be remembered for ushering in political reform.
sentences.chinese: 因引入政治改革而被人铭记的是蒋介石的儿子蒋经国。

sentences.english: Is it realistic of Chiang Ching kuo to propose unifying China with the "Three People's Principles"?
sentences.chinese: 蒋经国提出用“三民主义”统一中国，这现实吗？

definition: Chiang Wei-kuo (1916-1997), adopted son of Chiang Kai-shek 蔣介石|蒋介石
Chiang Kai-shek (1887-1975), military leader, head of the Nationalist government in China 1928-1949 and the government in exile on Taiwan 1950-1975

Li Zongren (1891-1969), a leader of Guangxi warlord faction
Soong Mei-ling (1898-2003), Chiang Kai-shek's second wife
honorific title for Chiang Kai-shek 蔣介石|蒋介石[Jiang3 Jie4 shi2]
Lee Teng-hui (1923-2020), Taiwanese politician, president of ROC 1988-2000
Wang Ching-wei (1883-1944), left-wing Guomingdang politician, subsequently Japanese collaborator

Guomindang or Kuomintang (KMT)/Nationalist Party
Bai Chongxi (1893-1966), a leader of Guangxi warlord faction, top Nationalist general, played important role in Chiang Kaishek's campaigns 1926-1949
